Question text: \text{Which of the following Langauges are residual Langages of }L((bba)^*b)
\text{Let }L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be a language with } LL = Σ^{*}. \text{ Which statements are true?}
Explanation1: If L were finite, LL would also be finite
Explanation2: Since ε ∈ Σ∗, ε must also be in LL, so ε ∈ L
Explanation3: It holds that LLL = Σ∗L ⊇ Σ∗ because ε ∈ L

Question text: \text{Let }L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be regular. Which of the following languages are regular? }
Explanation1: This is L^R L; closed under concatenation
Explanation3: Let L = (ba*). Then the language is { baⁿbaⁿ | n ∈ ℕ }, which is not regular.

Question text: \text{ Which of the following context-free grammars are ambiguous?}
Explanation2: Terminals are generated right to left
Answer3: S → TT; T → aT | bT | a | b

Question text: \text{ Let }A ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be regular and } B⊆ Σ^* \text{ context-free. Which of the following languages are context-free?}
Explanation2: A is regular ⇒ context-free; union of context-free languages is closed
Explanation3: A is context-free; concatenation is closed

Question text: \text{ Let } L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be a finite language with } |L| = |L^∗|.\text{ Which statements are true?}
\text{ Let } L ⊆ Σ^∗\text{ and }L' := {w ∈ L : |w|² ≤ 10|w|}.\text{ Which statements are true?}
\text{Let } L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be regular and } k > 0.\text{ Which of the following languages are regular?}
Explanation1: L ∩ (Σ^k)^* is regular; closed under intersection
Explanation3: For k = 2, known to be non-regular

Question text: \text{ Let }L ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be context-free. Which of the following languages are context-free?}
\text{ Let G be the grammar with productions } S → aT, T → Sb. \text{ Which statements are true? }
\text{We consider the language }L :=\{ aⁿbᵐcᵐ | n,m ∈ ℕ\} \text{ over } \{a,b,c\}.
Answer1: \text{ There exists a DPDA accepting L by final state }
Answer2: \text{ There exists an NFA recognizing L}
Answer3: \text{ There exists a DPDA accepting L by empty stack}

Answer1: \text{The set of regular languages is countable}
Answer2: \text{The set of languages that are not context-free is countable}
Answer3: \text{The set of languages that are context-free but not regular is countable}

Question text: \text{Let }A, B \text{ be languages over the same alphabet.}
Answer1: \text{ If  A and B are not regular, then } A ∪ B \text{ is not regular}
Answer2: \text{ If A is regular and B is context-free, then } A ∩ B \text{ is context-free}
Answer3: \text{If }A ∪ B = B ¸\text{ and }B \text{ is regular, then} A \text{ is regular}

Question text: \text{We consider the language }L := \{v₁bw₁\#v₂aw₂ | v₁ = v₂ ∧ w₁ = w₂\}.
\text{Let }A, B ⊆ Σ^∗ \text{ be languages. Which of the following statements are true?}
Answer2: \{uv : u ∈ A, v ∈ B\} = \{uv : u, v ∈ AB\}

Question text: \text{Let }M = (Q, Σ, δ, q₀, F) \text{be a DFA. A state } q ∈ Q \text{ is called a trap state if no final state is reachable from }q; i.e., ˆδ(q, w) ∉ F \text{ for all }w ∈ Σ^∗. \text{ For which of the following regular expressions r does there exist a DFA M with L(M) = L(r) and no trap state?}
Explanation1: (q₀, ba) is always a trap state
Explanation2: δ(q₀, a) is always a trap state
Explanation3: From every state, reading ba leads to acceptance
